channel.title: Science
channel.description:
:D true and false if anyone wants to help :D
1: Spores are usually fairly large and contain a good deal of stored food. True False
2: Some seed plants can be reproduced from parts of roots or stems. True False
3: Some flowers have petals and other flowers do not. True False
4: Anthers are structures that develop at the upper ends of pistils. True False
5: All flowers develop both stamens and pistils. True False
6: The ovary of a flower is located at the lower end of the pitsil. True False
7: Flowers that are wind-pollinated are likely to be incomplete. True False
8: Pollen grains are developed from parts of the plant ovary. True False
9: Hay fever may be caused by inhaling the pollen of golden rod plants. True False
10: In cross-pollination, pollen from the anthers of one flower is conveyed to the stigmas of other flowers. True False
11: A pollen tube is developed from a pollen grain that has reached the right kind of stigma. True False
12: If a mature sperm nucleus contains six chromosomes, a fertilized egg of the same species will also contain six chromosomes. True False
13: Seeds of flowering plants contain plant embryos and stored foods. True False
14: A newly sprouted monocot plant has two seed leaves. True False
15: Some fruits are dry and hard, but other fruits are fleshy. True False
16: Fruits are developed from fleshy parts of stamens. True False
17: White potatoes are generally produced by planting their seeds. True False
18: Some plants can be produced from underground parts such as bulbs or tubers. True False
19: A new plant which develops from a cutting has only one parent plant. True False
20: When a fruit tree scion is grafted on a stock, the stock is the part that will eventually produce the fruit. True False

item.title: Science
item.dc:creator: @afi afi
item.description:
@afi wrote:

o, thats a huge different grade system over there then over here +O[br][size=1]Posted at: May 11, 2006, 07:56:58 am[/size][hr]Heres alot more but after these two Illl be done I thinK
1: Lamarck was strongly opposed to the idea that acquired characteristics could be inherited.
True
False

2: Charles Darwin is genreally credited with developing the theory of natural selection.
True
False

3: Weismann denied the inheritance of acquired characteristics.
True
False

4: DeVries developed his mutation theory as a result of studies in which he used white rats.
True
False

5: Plants growing close together compete with one another for soil moisture, minerals, and sunlight.
True
False

6: In nature, fitness depends upon the existing conditions of life.
True
False

7: If an acquired characteristic makes an individual fit for survival, this characteristic will be passed onto the offspring.
True
False

8: When environments change, populations of plants and animals change also.
True
False

9: In natural selection, the nature of the environment determines whether a given characteristic is harmful or useful.
True
False

10: Artificial selection refers to methods we use to improve our cultivated plants and domesticated animals.
True
False

11: Some species are dispersed becuase they are accidentally transported by man.
True
False

12: Place of origin has very little to do with the present distribution of any species.
True
False

13: All species are about equally able to survive in different environments.
True
False

14: Some species have become much more widely dispersed than have other species.
True
False

15: A species is not affected by natural selection so long as it remains in its homeland.
True
False

16: The house rat has the ability to adapt to many different environments.
True
False

17: The long-day theory suggests that God used evolution to create the universe and everything in it.
True
False

18: Short-day theorists believe that creation took place in six 24-hour days.
True
False

19: The canopy theory is based on the interpretation os a “gap” between Genesis 1:1 and Genesis 1:2.
True
False

20: II Peter 3:8 is used as the justification of the long-day theory.
True
False

1: The native populations of a community make up its wildlife.
True
False

2: Cover consists of places where animals can take refuge from their enemies.
True
False

3: Most of the animal species that live in a forest are better able to survive if the forest is destroyed.
True
False

4: Many types of wildlife are imoprtant links in food chains.
True
False

5: When man moves into a forest community there is no affect on the forest.
True
False

6: Plywood is a building material that is made from the cotton plant.
True
False

7: Many types of cloth are made from plant fibers.
True
False

8: About the only modern uses of forest products are as fuels and lumber.
True
False

9: There is more forest land in the United States today than there was in the days of the first settlers.
True
False

10: Good quality paper is made primarily of cellulose.
True
False

11: Most of the fish that we eat today come from lakes and rivers.
True
False

12: The Great Lakes and the Mississippi river system provide our largest supply of freshwater fish.
True
False

13: Native supplies of oysters have increased about as fast as man has used them.
True
False

14: True lobsters have giant claws.
True
False

15: A “soft shelled crab” is an ordinary crab that recently shed its skeleton.
True
False

16: Most of the plants we raise today are descended from species grown many years ago.
True
False

17: Most citrus fruits are thought to have had their origin in the Americas.
True
False

18: The navel or seedless orange is the result of a cross between a sweet and a sour orange.
True
False

19: It is sometimes possible to get a twig of one kind of tree to grow on a stem of another kind.
True
False

20: Most domesticated animals compete directly with man for food.
True
False

21: Among the animals most recently domesticated are foxes and minks.
True
False

22: In recent years, the human population has decilned and there is an indication that this trend will continue.
True
False

1: Yeast cells reproduce by budding.
True
False

2: When conditions are favorable, certain microorganisms may grow and reproduce in a matter of minutes.
True
False

3: Spores sometimes travel in air as dust particles.
True
False

4: Mosses and ferns are seed producing plants.
True
False

5: A spore is a many-celled structure.
True
False

6: A new plant, growing from a single leaf, is an example of sexual reproduction.
True
False

7: Lizards can regenerate lost parts, but crabs and starfish cannot.
True
False

8: Flatworms sometimes reproduce by constricting themselves in the middle and separating into two halves.
True
False

9: A zygote results from the union of an egg and sperm cell.
True
False

10: Lack of oxygen in a pond may be a limiting factor.
True
False

11: Acquired characteristics can be passed on to an organism’s offspring.
True
False

12: Scientists claim that the oldest fossils are at the bottom of the fossil record.
True
False

13: What is a nerve cell called?
neuron
nerve
ganglion
stimulus

14: Which vessels carry blood toward the heart?
capillaries
arteries
aortic arches
veins

15: What are the smallest blood vessels called?
capillaries
arteries
aortic arches
veins

16: What is the term for the place where two or more bones meet?
joint
ligament
tendon
cartilage

17: What organ has involuntary, striated muscles?
stomach
intestines
heart
diaphragm

18: What kinds of joints do not allow movement?
hinge joints
ball and socket joints
pivot joints
fused joints

19: The preservation and wise use of natural resources is called ________.
recycling
rotation
conservation
farming

20: Usable materials that man can obtain from the physical world are called _______.
fertilizers
renewable resources
natural resources
fossil fuels

21: When no members of a species are left alive on earth, the species is ______.
endangered
extinct
ancient
fossilized

22: What is the term for maintaining conditions necessary for an egg to hatch?
fertilization
incubation
gestation
embryogenesis

23: What animal organ produces eggs?
ovule
ovary
testes
ovum

24: What does the word external mean in external fertilization?
fertilization occurs outside of the egg
fertilization occurs inside of the sperm
fertilization occurs outside of the mother’s body
fertilization occurs inside of the mother’s body

25: The diploid cell that results from fertilization is called a(n) _______.
egg
sperm
zygote
embryo

26: What animal organ produces sperm?
seminal vesicle
ovary
uterus
testis

27: How many sets of an organism’s chromosomes are contained within a gamete?
zero
one
two
three

28: What organ filters wastes from mammalian blood?
ureter
urinary bladder
kidney
lung

29: The bellybutton is the place where the ____ was attached to the fetus.
placenta
amniotic membrane
yolk sac
umbilical cord

30: What name is given to the reproductive cells produced by males?
sperm
ovum
testes
ovaries

31: What name is given to the uniting of gametes?
embryogenesis
meiosis
fertilization
conjugation

32: What is the term for animals’ inactivity and hiding underground during hot summer days?
laziness
naptime
hibernation
estivation

33: What two minerals are especially important in giving bones their strength?
magnesium and zinc
calcium and iron
magnesium and phosphorus
calcium and phosphorus

34: The black “hole” of the eye is the
cornea
lens
iris
pupil

35: What are cells that have axons and dendrites called?
spindles
villi
neurons
cilia

36: The largest part of the brain is the
cerebrum
cerebellum
medulla
brain stem

37: The clear covering over the sclera of the eye is the
cornea
lens
pupil
iris

38: What endrocrine gland produces insulin?
liver
pancreas
pituitary
thyroid

39: Name the microscopic structures in your lungs where gas exchange occurs.
tracheae
bronchioles
bronchi
alevoli

40: What muscle do you use to inhale?
stomach
lungs
diaphragm
rectus abdominis

41: Which type of blood cell transports oxygen?
red corpuscle
white corpuscle
platelet
plasma

42: What arteries nourish the heart?
pulmonary arteries
coronary arteries
aortic arches
systemic arteries

43: What is the largest artery in the body?
pulmonary artery
coronary artery
aorta
atrium

44: What does sugar in the urine indicate?
Lyme disease
cancer
kidney failure
diabetes

45: What is a common waste substance in the urine that is produced from protein digestion?
urea
water
salt
none of the above

46: Prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase are the four phases of
mitosis
meiosis
cytokinesis
cell cycle

47: What is the name of the monk who is considered the “father of modern genetics”?
Leeuwenhoek
Mendel
Linnaeus
deVries

48: Who proposed the theory of natural selection?
Linneaus
deVries
Lamarck
Darwin

49: Who proposed the theory of inheritance of acquired characteristics?
Linneaus
Lamarck
Darwin
deVries

50: How many chromosomes does a normal human cell have?
23
46
64
32

51: What kind of relationship is illustrated by a lichen?
competition
commensalism
epiphyte
mutualism

52: A(n) _______ animal is an animal that lives in a group.
social
independent
predatory
scavengering

53: _____________ may occur when an essential factor is in short supply.
commensalism
mutualism
mating
competition

Everyone please don’t say anything mean please +( I hate science

Read full topic

item.title: Science
item.dc:creator: @Friday13th Friday13th
item.description:
@Friday13th wrote:

;] nice to know that I have helped you any way…
Btw I had to use google to find what a B+ is - we have other grades system in Poland
…
something like this:

6 - its the best grade you can get, I gues something like A … You get 6 if you know more then you should
5 - its a good grade
4 - standard grade
3 - the minimum you have to know to pass a test
2 - if you know something but you are not able to get 3 ( wich is an positive grade and allows you to pass anything )
1 - if you just dont know anything …

Note: 1-2 are the grades that dont allow you to pass the test

we use halfs too eg: 4.5 or 4+ wich is somewhere between 4-5 common reason … :]
so if you have B+ it means that You have 5+ in our system wich is v.good grade

Read full topic

item.title: Science
item.dc:creator: @afi afi
item.description:
@afi wrote:

[quote=“Friday13th, post:7, topic:2532”]omg … You again !!! ?? 1 question … do you learn at school or just leach here
anyway here is my help

OMG HOW I HATE PLANTS

1: Spores are usually fairly large and contain a good deal of stored food.
[red]False[/red] - usually thay just v.small
2: Some seed plants can be reproduced from parts of roots or stems.
[red]True[/red] - i think yes because if you take a part of that plant and you put it in the wather then it will grow and create a new plant. So well its a kind of reproduction isnt it ?
3: Some flowers have petals and other flowers do not.
[red]True[/red] - eg some trees dont have petals
4: Anthers are structures that develop at the upper ends of pistils.
what does anter mean in english ??
5: All flowers develop both stamens and pistils.
[red]False[/red]
6: The ovary of a flower is located at the lower end of the pitsil.
[red]True[/red]
7: Flowers that are wind-pollinated are likely to be incomplete.
[red]True[/red]
8: Pollen grains are developed from parts of the plant ovary.
[red]False[/red]
9: Hay fever may be caused by inhaling the pollen of golden rod plants.
[red]True[/red]
10: In cross-pollination, pollen from the anthers of one flower is conveyed to the stigmas of other flowers.
[red]False[/red]
11: A pollen tube is developed from a pollen grain that has reached the right kind of stigma.
[red]False[/red]
12: If a mature sperm nucleus contains six chromosomes, a fertilized egg of the same species will also contain six chromosomes.
[red]False[/red] - it will have 2x more
13: Seeds of flowering plants contain plant embryos and stored foods.
[red]True[/red]
14: A newly sprouted monocot plant has two seed leaves.
[red]False[/red]
15: Some fruits are dry and hard, but other fruits are fleshy.
[red]True[/red]
16: Fruits are developed from fleshy parts of stamens.
[red]False[/red]
17: White potatoes are generally produced by planting their seeds.
[red]False[/red]
18: Some plants can be produced from underground parts such as bulbs or tubers.
[red]True[/red]
19: A new plant which develops from a cutting has only one parent plant.
[red]True[/red]
20: When a fruit tree scion is grafted on a stock, the stock is the part that will eventually produce the fruit.
[red]False[/red]

[hr]

and here are the questions you posted last - YEAH ANIMALS

1: Certain types of animals are able to reproduce asexually.
[red]True[/red]
2: Adult sponge and coral colonies are able to move around on the bottom of the shallow sea.
[red]True[/red] - as for coral colonies they cant move by them self but they can be moved by other animals
3: Sponges and coral develop special sex cells and free swimming embryos.
[red]True[/red]
4: Among flatworms, the testes and ovaries are formed in different individuals.
eee what is a flatworm ?? dont know that english word
5: Some species of planaria reproduce by forming male and female sex cells.
[red]True[/red] - I hope that planaria means that what I think it means
6: Earthworms are unable to regenerate parts.
and agian what is means that damn earthworm… dont have a good dictionary here
7: The eggs of a female oyster are fertilized before they are discharged into the water.
[red]False[/red] - dont tkink so
8: As soon as they are mature, a female crayfish discharges her eggs into the surrounding water.
[red]False[/red]
9: A number of vertebrates that live in the water reproduce by budding.
[red]False[/red]
10: Among the fish, individuals are usually either males or females.
[red]True[/red]
11: Some species of fish do not lay eggs but bear their young.
[red]True[/red]
12: A female frog’s eggs are fertilized before they leave her body cavity.
[red]False[/red]
13: A very young frog tadpole has gills on the outside of its body.
[red]False[/red] - Im not sure of this one …
14: Some species of reptiles are egg layers, but other reptiles bear their young.
[red]True[/red]
15: Young birds are usually able to find their own food about 24 hours after they have hatched.
[red]False[/red]
16: The female duckbill is unusual because she does not produce milk.
[red]False[/red] - if duckbill is that what I think it is I think she does
17: The young of kangaroos and opossums are quite immature at the time of birth.
[red]True[/red]
18: The placenta is a structure that serves to nourish a developing, but unborn, mammal.
[red]True[/red] - if placenta means that what I think it means then its true
19: The hen egg is fertilized after shell formation.
[red]False[/red][/quote]

Yeah… :P, How i hate homeschoool my sister just had to go off and have a baby thats why im home schooled this year -.-

Friday I’d never though I’d meet you and quite honstley get to say this but you got me an B+ how much I love you ( But not in a gay way) ;p + rep

Read full topic

2: Some seed plants can be reproduced from parts of roots or stems.

False

False

item.title: Science
item.dc:creator: @afi afi
item.description:
@afi wrote:

true and false if anyone wants to help

1: Spores are usually fairly large and contain a good deal of stored food.
True
False

2: Some seed plants can be reproduced from parts of roots or stems.
True
False

3: Some flowers have petals and other flowers do not.
True
False

4: Anthers are structures that develop at the upper ends of pistils.
True
False

5: All flowers develop both stamens and pistils.
True
False

6: The ovary of a flower is located at the lower end of the pitsil.
True
False

7: Flowers that are wind-pollinated are likely to be incomplete.
True
False

8: Pollen grains are developed from parts of the plant ovary.
True
False

9: Hay fever may be caused by inhaling the pollen of golden rod plants.
True
False

10: In cross-pollination, pollen from the anthers of one flower is conveyed to the stigmas of other flowers.
True
False

11: A pollen tube is developed from a pollen grain that has reached the right kind of stigma.
True
